name: Expired Antibiotics (Amoxicillin)
description: Capsules or tablets that have passed expiration date
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove antibiotics from original container
Step 2: Mix with undesirable substance (coffee grounds, dirt, or cat litter)
Step 3: Place mixture in sealed plastic bag or container
Step 4: Remove any personal information from prescription label
Step 5: Place sealed container in regular trash
Step 6: Do NOT flush down toilet or drain as it contaminates water supply

name: Insulin Pens & Needles
description: Used insulin delivery devices and sharps
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Place used needles immediately in FDA-cleared sharps container
Step 2: If no sharps container available, use heavy-duty plastic bottle with screw-on cap
Step 3: Label container clearly as 'SHARPS - DO NOT RECYCLE'
Step 4: When container is 3/4 full, seal cap with heavy-duty tape
Step 5: Check local regulations for sharps disposal locations
Step 6: Never place loose sharps in regular trash or recycling

name: Opioid Pain Relievers
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Mix pills with activated charcoal or coffee grounds in sealed bag
Step 2: Add small amount of water to begin dissolution
Step 3: Seal in second bag to prevent leakage
Step 4: Dispose in designated pharmaceutical waste container
Step 5: Record disposal in facility log with date and quantity
Step 6: Alternative: Use FDA-approved drug deactivation pouches if available

name: Chemotherapy Drugs
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Wear double gloves and protective equipment during handling
Step 2: Place drugs in yellow chemotherapy waste container
Step 3: Do NOT mix with regular pharmaceutical waste
Step 4: Seal container when 3/4 full with hazardous waste tape
Step 5: Label with date, drug name, and 'CYTOTOXIC WASTE'
Step 6: Store in designated secure area until licensed hazardous waste pickup
Step 7: Maintain disposal records for minimum 3 years

name: Liquid Cough Syrup
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Pour liquid into disposable container
Step 2: Add absorbent material (sawdust, cat litter, flour) equal to liquid volume
Step 3: Stir mixture until fully absorbed
Step 4: Seal container with lid and tape
Step 5: Remove label from original bottle
Step 6: Rinse empty bottle and recycle if possible
Step 7: Place sealed container in regular trash

name: Anticoagulants (Warfarin)
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Count remaining tablets and document quantity
Step 2: Crush tablets using mortar and pestle or in sealed bag
Step 3: Mix crushed medication with coffee grounds or soil
Step 4: Add small amount of dish soap to mixture
Step 5: Place in sealed plastic container or zip-lock bag
Step 6: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste bin, NOT regular trash
Step 7: Clean tools used with hot soapy water

name: Hormone Therapy Patches
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Fold used patch in half with sticky sides together
Step 2: Place folded patch in original pouch if available
Step 3: If no pouch, wrap in aluminum foil
Step 4: Place wrapped patches in sealed plastic bag
Step 5: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste or sealed regular trash
Step 6: Wash hands thoroughly after handling
Step 7: Never cut or tear patches as this releases medication

name: Expired Epinephrine Auto-Injectors
description: EpiPens and similar devices past expiration
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Activate auto-injector into thick cloth or paper towels to empty medication
Step 2: Wrap used device in several layers of newspaper
Step 3: Place in rigid plastic container or sharps container
Step 4: Seal container with heavy-duty tape
Step 5: Label as 'USED MEDICAL DEVICE'
Step 6: Contact local waste management for sharps disposal guidelines
Step 7: Never attempt to disassemble the device

name: Antidepressants (SSRIs)
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove tablets from blister packs or bottle
Step 2: Crush tablets with back of spoon in sealed bag
Step 3: Mix with used coffee filters or tea bags
Step 4: Add enough water to create paste consistency
Step 5: Transfer to sealed plastic container
Step 6: Remove all identifying information from original packaging
Step 7: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste or regular trash
Step 8: Do not dispose in sink or toilet to prevent water contamination

name: Insulin Vials
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Draw out remaining insulin with syringe
Step 2: Dispose syringe in sharps container
Step 3: Rinse empty vial with hot water three times
Step 4: Add small amount of bleach solution (10%) to vial
Step 5: Let sit for 5 minutes
Step 6: Pour out bleach solution in sink with running water
Step 7: Wrap vial in paper and place in sealed container
Step 8: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste or regular trash

name: Aerosol Inhalers
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Check if inhaler is completely empty by checking dose counter
Step 2: Remove metal canister from plastic holder if possible
Step 3: Wrap canister in plastic bag (still pressurized)
Step 4: Do NOT puncture or incinerate canister
Step 5: Place wrapped canister in pharmaceutical waste
Step 6: Plastic holder can be rinsed and recycled
Step 7: If partially full, treat as hazardous aerosol waste

name: Antibiotic Ointments
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Squeeze all remaining ointment onto paper towels
Step 2: Fold paper towels to contain ointment
Step 3: Place in sealed plastic bag
Step 4: Cut empty tube to ensure complete emptying
Step 5: Rinse tube with hot water
Step 6: Check if tube is recyclable (usually #5 plastic)
Step 7: Dispose sealed bag in regular trash
Step 8: Recycle tube if facility accepts it

name: Blood Glucose Test Strips
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Collect used strips in small plastic container with lid
Step 2: Do not mix with sharps or needles
Step 3: When container is full, seal with tape
Step 4: Label as 'USED TEST STRIPS'
Step 5: Dispose in regular trash
Step 6: Alternative: Some manufacturers accept returns for recycling
Step 7: Never flush or pour down drain

name: Vaccine Vials (Empty)
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Ensure vial is completely empty
Step 2: Rinse vial with 70% alcohol solution
Step 3: Let air dry for 10 minutes
Step 4: Wrap in paper to prevent glass breakage
Step 5: Place in rigid plastic container
Step 6: Seal container and label 'GLASS - BIOLOGICAL WASTE'
Step 7: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste stream
Step 8: Document disposal date and vaccine type in facility log

name: Antimicrobial IV Solutions
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Disconnect IV bag from administration set
Step 2: Seal port with sterile cap
Step 3: Place in puncture-resistant container
Step 4: Pour any excess liquid into absorbent pad in container
Step 5: Seal container when 3/4 full
Step 6: Label with drug name and 'PHARMACEUTICAL WASTE'
Step 7: Store in designated area until licensed disposal
Step 8: Never pour IV solutions down sink or toilet

name: Nitroglycerin Tablets
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Handle with gloves as medication absorbs through skin
Step 2: Place tablets in small glass container
Step 3: Add water to begin dissolving tablets
Step 4: After dissolution, add coffee grounds to mixture
Step 5: Seal container with screw-top lid
Step 6: Wrap container in plastic bag
Step 7: Label 'DISSOLVED MEDICATIONS'
Step 8: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste bin
Step 9: Wash hands thoroughly even after glove use

name: Corticosteroid Pills
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove tablets from packaging
Step 2: Crush tablets using pill crusher or sealed bag method
Step 3: Mix crushed medication with kitty litter or sawdust
Step 4: Add small amount of vinegar to neutralize
Step 5: Place mixture in sealed plastic container
Step 6: Tape lid securely
Step 7: Remove personal information from prescription label
Step 8: Dispose in pharmaceutical waste or regular trash

name: Eye Drop Solutions
description: Medicated eye drops in small bottles
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Pour remaining liquid onto paper towels
Step 2: Fold paper towels and place in plastic bag
Step 3: Seal bag to prevent leakage
Step 4: Remove dropper tip from bottle
Step 5: Rinse bottle with warm water
Step 6: Check if bottle is recyclable plastic
Step 7: Recycle bottle if possible, otherwise dispose with regular trash
Step 8: Dispose sealed bag with liquid in regular trash

name: Disposable Syringes
description: Used plastic syringes with or without needles
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Do NOT recap the needle after use
Step 2: Immediately place entire syringe in rigid sharps container
Step 3: If no sharps container, use thick plastic laundry detergent bottle
Step 4: Ensure container is puncture-proof and leak-resistant
Step 5: Fill container only to 3/4 full mark
Step 6: Seal container permanently with heavy-duty tape
Step 7: Label clearly 'BIOHAZARD SHARPS'
Step 8: Never place in regular trash or recycling bins

name: IV Sets and Tubing
description: Used intravenous administration sets and tubes
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Disconnect IV set from patient and solution bag
Step 2: Clamp all open ports to prevent fluid leakage
Step 3: Wrap tubing to prevent tangling
Step 4: Place in leak-proof red biohazard bag
Step 5: If contaminated with blood, treat as infectious waste
Step 6: Seal bag when 3/4 full
Step 7: Label with date and contents
Step 8: Store in designated biohazard waste area for pickup

name: Contaminated Gloves
description: Used latex, nitrile, or vinyl examination gloves
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove gloves using proper technique (glove-to-glove, skin-to-skin)
Step 2: Turn gloves inside out during removal
Step 3: Place immediately in red biohazard bag
Step 4: If heavily soiled with blood or body fluids, double-bag
Step 5: Never reuse disposable gloves
Step 6: Seal bag when 3/4 full
Step 7: Dispose as infectious waste
Step 8: Wash hands thoroughly after glove removal

name: Used Surgical Masks
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove mask by elastic loops without touching front
Step 2: Fold mask in half with contaminated side inward
Step 3: Place in designated yellow infectious waste bag
Step 4: If used in isolation or surgery, treat as biohazard
Step 5: Seal bag tightly
Step 6: Perform hand hygiene immediately
Step 7: Do NOT place in regular waste bins
Step 8: Store in secure area until professional disposal

name: Contaminated Bandages and Dressings
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Use gloves when handling soiled dressings
Step 2: Place directly into red biohazard bag
Step 3: If heavily saturated, wrap in absorbent pad first
Step 4: Do NOT squeeze or compress to remove fluids
Step 5: Seal inner bag before placing in outer container
Step 6: Label as 'INFECTIOUS WASTE'
Step 7: Store in leak-proof container
Step 8: Dispose through regulated medical waste service

name: Contaminated Cotton Swabs and Gauze
description: Used cotton materials with minimal contamination
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Assess level of contamination (blood, pus, or body fluids)
Step 2: If lightly soiled, place in yellow bag for general medical waste
Step 3: If heavily contaminated, treat as biohazard (red bag)
Step 4: Wrap in absorbent material if wet
Step 5: Seal bag to prevent odor and leakage
Step 6: Label appropriately based on contamination level
Step 7: Store away from patient care areas
Step 8: Follow facility protocols for pickup schedule

name: Used Blood Collection Tubes (Vacutainers)
description: Glass or plastic tubes containing blood samples
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Keep tubes sealed to prevent spills
Step 2: Place directly in rigid sharps container or biohazard box
Step 3: Do NOT empty tubes before disposal
Step 4: If tube breaks, use spill kit and place debris in separate bag
Step 5: Handle with forceps or gloves, never bare hands
Step 6: Label container 'BIOHAZARD - BLOOD PRODUCTS'
Step 7: Store in designated laboratory waste area
Step 8: Autoclave before final disposal if required by facility

name: Disposable Scalpels and Surgical Blades
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Do NOT remove blade from handle
Step 2: Place entire scalpel in puncture-proof sharps container immediately
Step 3: If blade must be removed, use blade remover device only
Step 4: Never use fingers to remove or bend blades
Step 5: Ensure sharps container is within arm's reach during procedure
Step 6: Fill container only to designated fill line
Step 7: Seal and label with biohazard symbol
Step 8: Follow facility protocol for sharps container replacement

name: Used Lancets
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Activate safety mechanism if available
Step 2: Place immediately in sharps container
Step 3: For home use, portable sharps containers are available at pharmacies
Step 4: Do NOT place in household trash or recycling
Step 5: Never reuse lancets
Step 6: Keep sharps container out of reach of children
Step 7: When container is 3/4 full, seal and tape shut
Step 8: Contact pharmacy or waste management for proper disposal options

name: Suture Needles and Material
description: Curved surgical needles with or without attached sutures
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Count all needles after procedure to ensure none are missing
Step 2: Place needles directly in sharps container using forceps
Step 3: Cut away excess suture material before disposal
Step 4: Never pass sharps hand-to-hand; use neutral zone
Step 5: Dispose contaminated suture material in biohazard bag
Step 6: Document needle count in patient record
Step 7: Report any missing needles immediately
Step 8: Ensure sharps container is stable and won't tip over

name: Urinary Catheters and Collection Bags
description: Used drainage systems and collection devices
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Wear gloves and protective equipment during removal
Step 2: Clamp catheter before disconnecting to prevent spillage
Step 3: Empty collection bag into designated sink or toilet
Step 4: Rinse drainage area with disinfectant
Step 5: Place catheter and bag in red biohazard bag
Step 6: Double-bag if bag is damaged or leaking
Step 7: Seal bag completely and label contents
Step 8: Perform hand hygiene thoroughly after disposal

name: Expired Saline and IV Solutions
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Check expiration date and verify it has passed
Step 2: Pour liquid contents into designated sink with running water
Step 3: Rinse empty bags or bottles with water
Step 4: Remove all labels containing patient information
Step 5: Puncture IV bags to ensure they cannot be reused
Step 6: Place empty containers in general waste
Step 7: Large quantities should be reported to waste coordinator
Step 8: Document disposal in facility log

name: Broken Mercury Thermometers
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Evacuate area and ventilate room immediately
Step 2: Wear gloves and avoid skin contact with mercury
Step 3: Use cardboard to gather mercury beads together
Step 4: Use eyedropper to collect mercury into sealed glass container
Step 5: Place all contaminated materials in zip-lock bag
Step 6: Label container 'MERCURY WASTE - HAZARDOUS'
Step 7: Contact environmental services for proper disposal
Step 8: Never vacuum mercury or wash down drain
Step 9: Document incident and disposal in safety log

name: Broken Glass Ampoules
description: Medication ampoules with sharp glass edges
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Use forceps or hemostats to handle broken glass
Step 2: Never pick up glass with bare hands
Step 3: Place broken ampoules in rigid sharps container
Step 4: If medication contaminated glass, treat as pharmaceutical waste
Step 5: Wipe surface with alcohol if medication spilled
Step 6: Dispose contaminated wipes in biohazard bag
Step 7: Label sharps container appropriately
Step 8: Report any cuts or punctures to supervisor immediately

name: Used Petri Dishes and Culture Plates
description: Agar plates with bacterial or fungal growth
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Seal plates with tape before removing from incubator
Step 2: Place sealed plates in autoclavable biohazard bag
Step 3: Autoclave at 121°C for 30 minutes minimum
Step 4: Allow to cool completely before handling
Step 5: After autoclaving, place in yellow infectious waste bag
Step 6: Label with autoclave date and contents
Step 7: Store in designated biohazard waste area
Step 8: Never dispose of unsterilized cultures

name: Contaminated Surgical Gowns
description: Disposable isolation gowns exposed to body fluids
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Remove gown from inside out, touching only interior surface
Step 2: Roll gown with contaminated side inward
Step 3: Place in red biohazard bag immediately
Step 4: If heavily soiled, place in leak-proof container first
Step 5: Do NOT shake or fold gown before disposal
Step 6: Seal bag when 3/4 full
Step 7: Store in designated area away from clean supplies
Step 8: Perform hand hygiene after removal

name: Used Biopsy Needles
description: Tissue sampling needles and core biopsy devices
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Activate needle safety mechanism immediately after use
Step 2: Place entire device in sharps container without delay
Step 3: Never disassemble or recap biopsy needles
Step 4: Ensure sharps container is within immediate reach
Step 5: If device has tissue sample, dispose of tissue separately in specimen container
Step 6: Label sharps container 'BIOHAZARD - CONTAMINATED SHARPS'
Step 7: Fill container only to marked line
Step 8: Document disposal in procedure log

name: Expired Diagnostic Reagents
description: Chemical solutions used in laboratory testing
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Identify chemical composition and hazard classification
Step 2: Check SDS (Safety Data Sheet) for disposal requirements
Step 3: Segregate incompatible chemicals
Step 4: Pour liquid reagents into labeled chemical waste container
Step 5: Do NOT mix different chemical wastes
Step 6: Keep original label on container
Step 7: Seal containers tightly to prevent evaporation
Step 8: Contact hazardous waste service for pickup
Step 9: Document disposal in chemical waste log

name: Used Oxygen Masks and Tubing
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Disconnect mask from oxygen source
Step 2: Remove mask from patient gently
Step 3: Coil tubing to prevent tangling
Step 4: Place in yellow general medical waste bag
Step 5: If contaminated with blood or secretions, use red biohazard bag
Step 6: Disinfect oxygen connection port on wall
Step 7: Seal bag when 3/4 full
Step 8: Replace with new equipment for next patient

name: Contaminated Specimen Containers
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Ensure container lid is sealed tightly
Step 2: Wipe exterior with disinfectant if soiled
Step 3: Place in rigid biohazard container
Step 4: If container leaks, place in secondary sealed bag
Step 5: Label outer container with specimen type
Step 6: Store in refrigerated biohazard area if required
Step 7: Autoclave before disposal if containing infectious material
Step 8: After autoclaving, dispose in general medical waste

name: Used Nebulizer Equipment
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Disconnect nebulizer from power source and tubing
Step 2: Disassemble all parts (mask, cup, mouthpiece)
Step 3: If disposable, place all parts in yellow medical waste bag
Step 4: If reusable, clean with disinfectant per manufacturer instructions
Step 5: Dispose tubing as general medical waste
Step 6: Rinse medication cup to remove residue
Step 7: Allow parts to air dry before storage or disposal
Step 8: Replace disposable parts after each patient use

name: Formalin-Fixed Tissue Samples
description: Preserved tissue specimens in formaldehyde solution
disposal_instructions:
Step 1: Keep specimens in sealed containers at all times
Step 2: Handle in fume hood due to formaldehyde vapors
Step 3: Wear double gloves and protective equipment
Step 4: Place containers in secondary containment
Step 5: Label as 'HAZARDOUS WASTE - FORMALDEHYDE'
Step 6: Do NOT pour formalin down drain
Step 7: Store in designated chemical waste area
Step 8: Contact licensed hazardous waste contractor for disposal
Step 9: Maintain disposal records for 5 years minimum
